awd_titl_txt: CAHSI INCLUDES Community Workshop on Building CISE Research Capacity at Hispanic-Serving Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the proposed two-day Computing Alliance of Hispanic-Serving Institutions (CAHSI) 
INCLUDES Community workshop is to bring together researchers from Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs) to co-develop an action plan to increase HSI representation in the Computer and Information Science & Engineering (CISE) directorate's portfolio. The investigators will facilitate focused discussions on the factors that support and impede HSIs in securing funding. It is critical for the health of our nation to build capacity at HSIs to conduct research and advance educational attainment in computing of Hispanics and other underrepresented students, including first-generation and low-income populations 
who are enrolled in high shares at most HSIs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Academy of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) report Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs): America's Underutilized Resource for Strengthening the STEM Workforce calls for increased federal investment in Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs) motivated by the realization that the United States is unlikely to maintain its competitive advantage in STEM without the contributions HSIs. Research suggests that the cultural diversity of a nation’s workforce is a key factor in its ability to innovate and compete in a global economy.

While federal agencies awarded a total of $30.5 billion in funding targeting STEM in academic institutions, just $783 million (less than 3% of that amount) went to MSIs, and 70% of the funds for MSIs went to only 20 MSIs. The Computing Alliance of Hispanic-Serving Institutions (CAHSI) National INCLUDES alliance presented an Ideas Lab to bring together Hispanic researchers and researchers from HSIs in intensive, facilitated meetings that focus on proposing research projects that address challenge problems in NSF Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) core areas. The Ideas-Lab concept originated at NSF with the intent to create a fertile, creative atmosphere that leads to new ideas and promotes team science.

CAHSI organized the Ideas workshop as a series of virtual meetings facilitated by the online tool Miro to capture ideas and feedback from potential teams of researchers. Researchers focused on addressing critical problems facing our society and planning research projects. More advanced researchers from CAHSI, Google researchers, and NSF program officers provided critical feedback on proposal research projects from the perspective of significance of the project, potential to be transformative, and alignment of proposed projects to NSF CISE core research areas.  Building a community of HSIs committed to improving research capacity and building infrastructure is expected to translate into more opportunities nationally for faculty collaboration and faculty members' ability to seek funding opportunities, especially for faculty who typically have not been engaged in research.

The Ideation Workshop involved the following:

  • Day 1:  All-Hands Convening I. Review of the project goals and expected outcomes, an overview from NSF regarding the importance of the project in advancing discovery and interactions with NSF program officers to learn about CISE research areas of interest.
  • Day 2 Focus Area: Smart Connected Health and Smart Cities. The session was organized with working group breakouts that included faculty, assigned facilitators, and mentors. The large group discussion focused on the research ideas that emerged with feedback from mentors.
  • Day 3 Focus Area: Cybersecurity.  Session was organized using the same structure as Day 2.
  • Day 4 Focus Area: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles and Artificial Intelligence. Session was organized using the same structure as Day 2.
  • Day 5:  All-Hands Convening II. Faculty were given a little over two weeks (prior to attending the Day 5 session) to meet with the research groups that were formed in Days 2-4. Participants were placed into breakout rooms to pitch their ideas, receive feedback, and refine their pitch before presenting to the large group for additional feedback.

 The teams worked a month and a half to develop their research plans. The groups that were able to refine their research plans over two months were invited to the American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE) workshop, Increasing Participation and Competitiveness of MSIs, to develop competitive proposals for the MSI CISE solicitation via a 5-session workshop with weekly instruction and assignments on critical proposal components with mentoring from CISE core researchers. A second ASEE workshop, Capacity Building for Research at Minority Serving Institutions, expanded the sessions of the previous ASEE workshop to include networking, ideation and teamwork tailored to build skills and encourage collaboration across MSI silos.

From the first CAHSI cohort, 54 faculty members were engaged in either the workshop or research proposal, 46 faculty from 29 institutions participated in the Ideation Workshop, 28 faculty were included in a research proposal in addition to an ARL researcher, and seven were funded in 2021 through the NSF MSI Expansion program.  Three more proposals were funded through the NSF MSI Expansion program in 2022.

CAHSI's expectation that the convenings will lead to collective efforts that will be far-reaching and can serve as a model has been realized through a multi-million dollar investment from Google. The three-year investment will build on the foundation of the Ideas Lab. In addition, to providing research experiences at students' home institutions, the funding will allow CAHSI to hold an annual Ideas Lab to identify innovative research efforts that align with Google's research interests.  The transformational change has the potential to meet the demand for diverse researchers who can contribute solutions to society's pressing problems.
